docs.snippet: THERE are members of the community who are dismayed when ever a production of Shakespeare's "The Merchant of Venice" is announced....
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are members of the community who are dismayed when ever a production of Shakespeare's "The Merchant of Venice" is announced.
docs.abstract: Comment on public reaction to planned presentation of Shakespeare play The Merchant of Venice by Lincoln Center Repertory Theater notes that co had recd some lrs and calls expressing concern over possible anti-Semitic overtones in play; lrs were fowarded to Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith; E Rabb, directing forthcoming production, says his view of Shylock is sympathetic; repr of league after viewing rehearsal of play reptdly emerged satisfied that there were no grounds for complaint; critic A Kazin says play is classic and must not be suppressed

headline.main: Shylock-Has the Storm Subsided?; News of the Itialto

docs.abstract: museum officials, archeologists and scholars throughout US on Feb 23 comment on $1-million paid by Met Museum for krater; while some feel price was 'ridiculous' and will encourage looting in future, others feel that cost should not be paramount consideration where invaluable work of art is concerned; events concerning purchase of vase and subsequent facts revealed by NY Times investigation recounted; crowds have been reptd going to museum just to see controversial vase

headline.main: Price Questioned; Museums Question Price and Secrecy in Purchase of Met Vase

docs.snippet: The United States and China took a step toward full diplomatic relations yesterday with the announcement that each Government would soon open a liaison office in the other's capital. In a news conference on the joint communique issued in Peking an...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States and China took a step toward full diplomatic relations yesterday with the announcement that each Government would soon open a liaison office in the other's capital. In a news conference on the joint communique issued in Peking and Washington, Henry A. Kissinger said. that additional steps to "accelerate" the improvement of relations had been agreed to. [Page 1, Column 8; Text, P. 15; Text of Mr. Kissinger's remarks, P. 14.]
